title: A t-test evaluates whether the difference between two means is larger than what random variation alone would produce.
There are three major types of t-tests: one-sample, independent samples, and paired samples.
A one-sample t-test compares a sample mean against a known or hypothesized population mean.
An independent samples t-test compares the means of two independent groups.
A paired samples t-test compares the mean difference within the same individuals across two time points or conditions.
The independence of observations is one of the most critical assumptions of all t-tests.
T-tests assume the dependent variable is continuous and approximately normally distributed within each group.
The independent t-test assumes equal variances across groups; if violated, use Welch’s t-test.
A significant t-test indicates evidence of a mean difference, not the magnitude or importance of that difference.
Effect sizes such as Cohen’s d, Hedges’ g, and Glass’s Δ provide insight into the practical importance of a t-test result beyond statistical significance.
Always report effect size with a t-test; statistical significance alone does not describe the practical impact.
In t-test, Cohen’s d measures how large the mean difference is in standardized units.
Confidence intervals surrounding the mean difference offer a clearer picture of the precision of your estimate.
A non-significant t-test does not prove that two groups are the same. It simply shows that the evidence is insufficient.
Larger sample sizes make t-tests more sensitive to detecting small but consistent differences.
Before running a t-test, visualize the data; plots can reveal group differences or assumption violations not visible in the numbers.
Report t-statistic, degrees of freedom, p-value, mean difference, and effect size for transparent communication.
The robustness of t-tests increases with balanced group sizes and minimal outliers.
Cohen’s d expresses the mean difference between two groups in standard deviation units, making the effect easy to interpret across studies.
Hedges’ g is a small-sample correction of Cohen’s d, providing a more accurate effect size when sample sizes are small or unequal.
Glass’s Δ uses only the standard deviation of the control group, making it useful when the two groups have very different variances.
Linear regression estimates how the expected value of an outcome changes with a one-unit change in a predictor.
The goal of linear regression is not perfect prediction, but interpretable relationships between variables.
Linear regression models conditional means, not individual outcomes.
In linear regression, the intercept represents the expected outcome when all predictors equal zero.
A linear regression coefficient quantifies average change while holding other predictors constant.
In linear regression, residuals represent the portion of the outcome the model cannot explain.
Linear regression assumes a systematic, linear relationship between predictors and the outcome.
Independence in linear regression requires that observations do not influence one another.
Homoscedasticity in linear regression means residual variance is constant across fitted values.
In linear regression, normality is an assumption about residuals—not the original variables.
Low multicollinearity in linear regression ensures each predictor contributes unique information.
Linear regression assumptions are evaluated through diagnostics, not intuition.
Residual plots are central to diagnosing assumption violations in linear regression.
In linear regression, influential observations matter because they can substantially alter estimates.
When linear regression is nonlinear, transformations or polynomial terms are often required.
Heteroscedasticity in linear regression calls for robust standard errors or weighted least squares.
Dependence in linear regression data requires clustered, mixed, or hierarchical modeling.
Multicollinearity in linear regression is addressed through centering, variable selection, or dimension reduction.
Outliers in linear regression should be investigated for meaning before any decision to remove them.
Linear regression results should be reported with effect sizes, uncertainty, and context.
Statistical significance alone is insufficient for interpreting linear regression results.
All conclusions from linear regression are conditional on model specification and assumptions.
